title: Progressive Left-Sided Hearing Loss with Intermittent Dizziness
chief_complaint: I noticed hearing loss in my left ear many years ago, and it has continued to decline. I also hear a hissing sound in that ear, and lately, I've been having spells of dizziness.

problem_summary.onset: Hearing loss noticed many years ago; dizziness started in the last few months.
problem_summary.course: Progressive decline in the left ear.
problem_summary.laterality: Left ear worse; right ear perceived as relatively good.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Hissing tinnitus in the left ear; intermittent dizziness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Noted decline in hearing ability in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking re-evaluation after being told previously there was 'nothing concerning'.

history.present_illness: Patient reports long-standing, progressive left-sided hearing loss and hissing tinnitus. Intermittent dizziness began a few months ago.
history.otologic_history: Previous exam years ago reportedly found 'nothing concerning'.
history.prior_management: Previous hearing exam (results unknown/unremarkable per patient report).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. Right ear shows slight low-frequency loss rising to normal at 1kHz, then sloping to severe in high frequencies. Left ear shows a 'trough' or complex shape: moderately severe rising to mild in mid-frequencies, then sloping to severe at 3-4kHz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores agree with PTA. Word recognition scores (WRS) show significant asymmetry, with the left ear performing notably worse than the right.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes generally elevated or absent, particularly at high frequencies. Contralateral decay could not be measured.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, with the left ear exhibiting a greater degree of loss and a complex configuration compared to the right. Word recognition is significantly poorer in the left ear (66%) compared to the right (84%). While middle ear function is normal, the asymmetry in thresholds, speech scores, and the presence of unilateral tinnitus and dizziness raise red flags for retrocochlear pathology.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms that the hearing in your left ear is significantly different from your right ear.
The word recognition score in your left ear is lower than we would expect based solely on the hearing loss levels.
Because of the difference between ears, the one-sided tinnitus, and the dizziness, we need to refer you to an ENT specialist.
An MRI will likely be recommended to rule out any issues along the hearing nerve (retrocochlear pathology).
Once we have medical clearance from the ENT, we can discuss hearing aids to help with the hearing loss.
notes_for_actor: You are 73 years old and frustrated that previous doctors told you nothing was wrong, yet your hearing kept getting worse.
The hissing sound in your left ear is constant and annoying.
The dizziness is a new symptom (last few months) and concerns you.
You perceive your right ear as 'good', even though the test shows some high-frequency loss there too.
